testimony.name: Austin Celestin
key_points: Current housing situation is unaffordable for many, including the speaker and his family
Low vacancy rates, slow construction pace, high rents, and increasing homelessness are major issues
Current zoning plan has reduced buildable capacity by 80% and led to housing loss in some neighborhoods
The City of Yes proposal caters to different neighborhood needs and capacities
Proposal includes various strategies like transit-oriented development, commercial conversions, ADUs, and lifting parking mandates
The plan is modest but ambitious, covering about 20% of the housing need
Urges the City Planning Commission to approve the City of Yes proposal and consider doing even more

quotes_indicating_discussion.reasoning: The speaker mentions commercial conversions for Midtown Manhattan, which directly relates to the residential conversions element of the City of Yes For Housing Opportunity proposal.

quotes_indicating_discussion.text: the underappreciated aspect of whipping parking mandates, which makes housing more expensive more expensive.
quotes_indicating_discussion.reasoning: The speaker mentions removing parking mandates as part of the proposal, highlighting that it makes housing less expensive, which aligns with the City Planning's description of this element.

quotes_indicating_discussion.text: ADU's full low density residential areas
quotes_indicating_discussion.reasoning: The speaker directly mentions ADUs (Accessory Dwelling Units) as part of the proposal, indicating that this element is discussed in the testimony.

quotes_indicating_discussion.text: transforming the development for those Attleboro communities near subways.
quotes_indicating_discussion.reasoning: The speaker mentions development near subways, which aligns with the transit-oriented development element of the proposal.
